Specification_Description: This section allows the agency to convey strategic and overarching agency goals to project bidders. Specification_Template_Language:
Include objectives for the solar PV system(s), for example:

  • Annual solar PV production is to be at least of annual site consumption (kWh), as averaged over the previous three years.

  • Exceed federal and internal agency sustainability mandates and goals.
  • Provide leadership by example within the federal government.

Specification_Description: This section provides much of the basic information that Contractors need to understand what will be expected of them and the solar PV system.
Specification_Template_Language:
The Contractor shall generate safe and reliable electricity from solar photovoltaic (PV) system(s) sited on over the contract life. The electricity shall feed into Government electrical distribution systems on the "customer side" of the utility meter. The Contractor will design and construct, own, and operate the solar PV system(s) built and operated on-site. The system will be owned by .If specified, the services of the Contractor shall include the operation and maintenance of the solar PV system(s).

The system shall convert solar radiation into AC electric power at a voltage compatible with the local utility grid power distribution system and acceptable to the local utility distribution company. At a minimum, each system shall consist of:

  • A solar PV generation system
  • All necessary support structures and mounting provisions
  • All necessary reinforcement of the existing support structure
  • Terminal and combiner boxes
  • Quick-connect solar panel electrical connector
  • Cable and wiring
  • Conduits
  • DC disconnect
  • Grid-tied inverter or module-level power electronics
  • AC disconnect
  • All metering and control equipment
  • System monitoring and data retrieval subsystem
  • Ground and arc fault protection and alarming
  • An electrical grounding subsystem
  • Everything necessary to interconnect with the site electrical distribution system

In addition, the Contractor shall provide all incidentals required, such as the agency's electrical distribution system impact studies and needed modifications, permits, approvals, environmental and historic compliance, freight, financing, procurement, monitoring, inspection, and billing as necessary to design, construct, operate, and maintain all the complete solar PV systems, described hereinafter.

Specification_Description: This section describes what the Contractor is responsible for from the start of the project to the end.
Specification_Template_Language:
The Contractor shall provide all labor, material, equipment, engineering, maintenance, and capital to design, install, commission, interconnect, maintain, and operate solar photovoltaic (PV) systems as required herein. The Government shall pay the Contractor solely on the basis of a price per kilowatt-hour plus an "Option Increment" of the power produced by each system and delivered to each Contractor-owned billing meter, as described herein.

The Contractor is responsible for permits, approvals, environmental and historic compliance, freight, financing, procurement, monitoring, inspection, billing, and incidentals as necessary to design, construct, interconnect, operate, and maintain the complete solar PV generation systems, described hereinafter. For ground-mounted arrays, the Contractor is responsible for all costs in establishing and maintaining grounds within the array boundary. All areas under the Contractor's control shall be maintained in a neat, clean fashion.

For third-party owned systems: The Contractor, or any special purpose entity designated by the Contractor, shall maintain title to the systems. The Government will grant utility easements to the Contractor for nonexclusive use of ground or parking lot space so the Contractor can keep and maintain the systems. The solicitation is structured with the intent for the Contractor to be able to take advantage of the solar investment tax credit (ITC) and accelerated depreciation. The Contractor is solely responsible for ensuring that the project meets the Internal Revenue Service Notice requirements for the desired ITC amount.

In addition, the Contractor shall provide all incidentals required, such as the agency's electrical distribution system impact studies and needed modifications, permits, approvals, environmental and historic compliance, freight, financing, procurement, monitoring, telemetry, inspection, and billing as necessary to design, construct, operate, and maintain all the complete solar PV systems, described hereinafter.

Specification_Description: This section describes language that an agency can use when faced with space constraints and the need to keep the PV array(s) as small as possible while also achieving maximum benefits.
Specification_Template_Language: Agency sites (roof, ground, and carport) with limited array surface areas shall be considered space constrained. In this case, open areas made available by federal agencies are to be viewed as a scarce resource. Federal agencies seek solar PV systems that are engineered and constructed with high-quality, efficient components and best practice methods in order to maximize kWh production and dollar savings per square foot. For sites with time-of-use (TOU) and/or demand rates, solar PV systems are to be designed to offset the greatest amount of electricity in higher cost-rate periods and achieve the greatest annual dollar savings.

Specification_Template_Language:
For system impact studies where the Government operates or owns the electrical distribution system, the Contractor is responsible for:

  1. A load flow protection coordination study, with the objective of revealing any existing protection equipment incompatibilities and/or unprotected lines.
  2. A study to identify existing distribution system components that are incompatible with the reliable, stable, and safe distribution of power generated by solar PV systems.

Specification_Title: Interconnection to Government-Owned Electrical Distribution Equipment (Advanced)
Specification_Description: This section describes the Contractor's responsibility to conduct any necessary modifications, upgrades, and/or system impact studies to the Government-owned electrical distribution system required for interconnection.
Specification_Template_Language:
Modifications or upgrades to the electrical system required to interconnect the PV systems are the responsibility of the Contractor. Any needed upgrades or modifications to existing agency electrical distribution systems must be included in the review and approval process outlined in the submittal section herein.

The Contractor is required to perform a system impact study of all Government-owned electrical distribution systems. The study shall identify existing conditions that would prohibit the distribution of power generated by a solar PV system in a safe and stable manner, without causing electrical outages or disturbances to commonly coupled facilities.

System impact studies of Government-owned electrical distribution systems must include a load flow protection coordination study with the objective of revealing any existing protection equipment incompatibilities and/or unprotected lines.

The results of impact and load flow studies that indicate needed upgrades and modifications to Government-owned electrical distribution systems shall be engineered, permitted, inspected, constructed, and paid for by the Contractor.

For sites with non-unity power factors, the addition of PV can further degrade the power factor (as seen by the utility). If the resulting power factor penalty charges justify the added investment cost, the inverters shall have the capability to adjust the site power factor to by sourcing or sinking reactive power. Adjustments shall be either programmed locally (autonomous control) or be implemented upon receipt of a variable power factor command provided by the remote power system controller. The inverters shall have a range of dynamic reactive capability that supports its operation from a [y] leading to [z] lagging power factor. The intent is to control power factor and to provide electrical distribution system support to the utility if requested. A non-unity power factor for the inverter shall be allowed. The inverter shall be capable of sourcing VARs even when the PV system is not operating. The Contractor shall be compensated for lost real energy (kWh) in exchange for sourcing VARs.

Specification_Description: This section describes the precautions that must be taken when sensitive electronic equipment is present at the facilities.
Specification_Template_Language:
In instances where solar PV systems are commonly coupled to a Government-owned electrical distribution system that serves sensitive electronic equipment, the following precautions must be implemented in collaboration with the Contracting Officer's Representative.

  • The Contractor will work with the Contracting Officer's Representative to confirm the location, manufacturer/model, and quantity of the sensitive equipment to produce a "sensitive equipment inventory."
  • The Contractor will confirm with the Contracting Officer's Representative that the sensitive equipment is protected with uninterruptible power supplies (UPS) or other protection hardware as specified by the equipment manufacturer. The Government is responsible for procuring and installing UPS systems.
  • Inverters will be set per IEEE 1547 Category 1 trip settings; IEEE 1547 "response to abnormal voltages and voltage ride-through requirement."

Specification_Description: This section describes the requirements for inverters to be able to effectively maintain minimum power factor levels.
Specification_Template_Language: If in any situation where the solar PV system is sufficiently large relative to site loads to cause an increase in reactive power (reduction in power factor), then inverters must be adjusted to adequately source and sink VARs, as a means to maintain minimum power factor levels. Minimum power factors levels are those provided by the serving utility tariff schedule.

Specification_Title: Interconnection to Franchise Utility-Owned Electrical Distribution Systems
Specification_Description: This section describes the Contractor's responsibility to conduct any necessary modifications, upgrades, and/or system impact studies to the franchise utility-owned electrical distribution system required for interconnection.
Specification_Template_Language:
The Contractor must meet all requirements from the local utility, public utilities commission, FERC, and any governing operating region organization (e.g., ERCOT, Cal-ISO, PJM).

The Contractor is responsible for complying with all electric utility interconnection requirements, including upgrades, telemetry, interconnection applications, and funding any required interconnection studies to be performed by or on behalf of the electric utility. The Contractor is responsible for recurring telemetry carrier and maintenance fees throughout the life of the contract.

Specification_Title: Interconnection to Franchise Utility-Owned Electrical Distribution Systems (Advanced)
Specification_Description: This section describes the Contractor's responsibility to conduct any necessary modifications, upgrades, and/or system impact studies to the franchise utility-owned electrical distribution system required for interconnection.
Specification_Template_Language:
The second set of requirements are imposed by local utility, public utilities commission, FERC, and any governing operating region organization (e.g., ERCOT, Cal-ISO, WREGIS, PJM) and applicable codes such as IEEE 1547. The Contractor shall provide interconnection of the PV system with the electrical distribution system and take actions to ensure that the two components are compatible. Modifications or upgrades to the electrical system for interconnection are the responsibility of the Contractor. The Contractor is responsible for the proper circuit sizing, overcurrent protection, and coordination of the circuit(s) beyond the point of interconnection, including modifications to the federal site's electrical equipment and circuits. The Contractor shall assume the costs of these modifications. Any modifications to the approved PV system design that would affect the electrical distribution system shall require the written approval of the Government.

The Contractor is responsible for complying with all electric utility interconnection requirements, including upgrades, telemetry, providing all necessary PV system details for the interconnection applications, and funding any required interconnection studies to be performed by or on behalf of the electric utility. The Contractor is responsible for gaining approval from the electric utility for interconnection and any electric utility-required upgrades, including recurring maintenance fees throughout the life of the contract. Telemetry requirements with recurring fees are the responsibility of the Contractor.

The Contractor shall submit an electric utility interconnection process plan to the Government within 14 days of the contract award. The plan shall include key steps, equipment and telemetry upgrades required, controls, timeline, interconnection details, and assumptions necessary to complete the interconnection process. The Government shall assist in facilitating communications with the franchise utility for this purpose. The electric utility interconnection agreements to connect the PV systems to the grid will be signed by the Government or Contractor as required by the franchise utility.

Modifications or upgrades to the electrical system required to interconnect the PV systems are the responsibility of the Contractor solely. The Contractor shall provide supporting material and analysis if required: single line diagrams, engineering power flow studies, estimated energy production data estimates, and other specifications and data with respect to the proposed new generating systems.

Any local codes required by utility interconnection laws and regulations shall be followed by the Contractor.

Specification_Description: This section describes the requirements for agencies and Contractors to conduct any NEPA studies and/or other environmental studies.
Specification_Template_Language:
The National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) requires federal agencies to consider the effects of their actions on the human environment and identify alternatives that have the potential to reduce the impacts of those actions. When significant impacts might occur from project development, detailed statements must be prepared for public and federal agency review. The Council on Environmental Quality's implementing instructions can be found at 40 CFR Parts 1500-1508, and the Government's implementing instructions can be found in the Public Building Service's NEPA Desk Guide October 1999.

  • State Historic Preservation Offices The Contractor shall comply with local, state, and federal State Historic Preservation Offices requirements.
  • Special Planning Commissions-Having Authority: The Contractor shall comply with and gain approval for the solar PV systems.

Construction Phase Environmental Management:

  • Hazardous Materials/Due Diligence: The Contractor shall indicate if any hazardous materials will be disturbed, encountered, or used in the construction of the solar PV system The Contractor shall provide all appropriate mitigation measures, if required, to reduce the impacts to insignificant levels.
  • Noise Pollution: The Contractor shall provide a description of construction activities and mitigation to reduce noise related to construction.
  • Traffic Impacts: The Contractor shall provide mitigation measures to reduce traffic impacts on local streets during construction (road/sidewalk closures, use of cranes, etc.).
  • Jurisdictional Approvals: The Contractor shall provide required development approvals from the county and/or municipality. It is understood that conformance to all applicable approvals is at the sole cost and expense of the Contractor.
  • Storm water Runoff Management: The Contractor shall provide sufficient documentation to demonstrate that the requirements of the Energy Independence and Security Act (EISA) Section 438 are being met. The Contractor shall not change the pattern of storm water amounts or runoff. If the project involves digging/trenching in soil of an area more than 50 linear feet, the Contractor must provide an erosion and sediment control plan.
  • Visual Impact Analysis: If the PV system will be visible from the ground or adjoining buildings, the Contractor shall provide viewshed drawings depicting the potential visual impacts of the solar PV installation.
Specification_Background:
Depending on the location or type of array, agencies may be required to undertake a full NEPA study prior to start of construction.

The Contractor might be asked to provide supporting documents, such as array layouts, to agency environmental officials.

Specification_Description: This section describes requirements from the Federal Communications Commission for solar PV systems to meet in regards to electromagnetic interference and setbacks.
Specification_Template_Language:
Per FCC CFR Title 47 Part 15B, the PV system shall not emit electromagnetic interference (EMI) that interferes with other communications, and incoming EMI shall not cause problems with the control or performance of the PV system. If the PV system emits EMI, the Contractor shall turn off the system and take sufficient measures to eliminate the emission of EMI prior to restarting the system.

The Contractor shall specify FCC Title 47 Part 15 Class A compliant equipment and implement a 250-foot setback (minimum) from the PV system to any existing radar equipment to minimize physical blocking or reflection of the radar signals. If siting near any existing Very High Frequency (VHF) Omnidirectional Range (VOR) equipment, the Contractor shall reference FAA Order 6820.10. For more information, please see NREL's publication "Photovoltaic Systems Near Airfields: Electromagnetic Interference."

Specification_Description: This section describes the requirements the Contractor must meet to involve the local fire marshal and comply with local fire codes.
Specification_Template_Language:
The Contractor shall involve the fire marshal or organization responsible for fire protection to provide design advice and design approval. The Contractor shall review the design of the system with the fire marshal and observe design guidelines regarding firefighter access in the International Association of Fire Fighters and the NEC 690 (2017).

The Contractor shall invite local firefighters to a training where firefighters will be shown how the system works and how to shut it down, and shall work with the fire marshal to determine where to post the permanent instructions and required markings. Specification_Title: Roof Arrays - Sloped Roofs - Severe Weather, High Wind Climates
Specification_Description: This section describes the requirement prohibiting installation on sloped roofs close to roof edges, hips, and valleys, where wind pressures are high relative to interior zones.
Specification_Template_Language:
The following principles taken from "RMI - Solar Under Storm 2" shall be followed:

  1. The roof shall be zoned into pressure zones as shown on page 30. The structural engineer is to stay within Zone 1 - the "Green Zone" - which shall also meet fire code required setbacks from roof edges and hips and valleys.

Specification_Description: This section describes the module specifications and mounting details needed to prevent the module from dislodging from the rack.
Specification_Template_Language:
1. Use of 5400 Pa front load rated modules required.
2. To gain full rated 5400 Pa strength, the Contractor shall consult the module manufacturer and prescribe the mounting details:

2a. Minimum number of rails recommended.
2b. Module manufacturer approved fastener specifications.
2c. Module manufacturer approval of ideal location of fasteners on frame. The ideal position of the fasteners shall be based on wind tunnel testing, however module recommendations based on UL 2703 is sufficient for warranty purposes.

3. The type of mounting fastener must be specified with three important considerations as to the choice of fasteners:

3a. Through-bolting modules to mounting rails shall be explored with the module manufacturer as a first choice.
3b. If top-down clamps are necessary, use a style that prevents "row domino" (see figure.)
3c. Any fasteners used to secure modules shall include rated locking fasteners based on DIN-65151.
3d. Top-down module clamps are to be considered a special case "soft joint" and require spring/cupped style washers to ensure clamp loading is maintained.

4. Deflection and torsional bending of the underlying rack framing shall be highlighted and addressed by a structural engineer to prevent undue stress on the modules mounted above.

Specification_Title: Modules in Severe Weather - Wind: Fasteners
Specification_Description: Describes a preference to through bolt where possible.
Specification_Template_Language:
1. Specify PV panels and rail/rack systems that have UL 1703 and UL 2703 listing (as applicable), and an ICC AC 428 evaluation report.
  2. Fastener failures are a common primary point of failure for PV systems in severe weather, so this system requires robust design and quality installation of all bolted joints.
  3. Modules shall be through-bolted to the underlying racking only; top down clamps should not be used under any circumstances.
  4. Threaded fasteners should include locking mechanisms to address both preload relaxation and joint slip.
  5. Spring/cupped washers such as Belleville washers shall be used to compensate for preload relaxation, as specified by the structural engineer.
  6. Wedge-lock washers and pre-applied thread lock can help mitigate slip in the bolted joint, fasteners should be designed and installed by the structural engineer in accordance with standard DIN 65151.
  7. Under no circumstances shall split washers, nylon-insert nuts, double-nutting, star washers, and/or serrated flange nuts be used to provide fastener locking capability.
Specification_Topic: Codes and Standards; Cybersecurity; Engineering; O&M; Resiliency; Safety; Severe Weather

Specification_Description: This section describes the test parameters for snow, hail and wind loading that the PV modules must meet.
Specification_Template_Language: PV Modules shall be tested per ASTM E1830-15, which prescribes test parameters for loading (snow and wind) of solar modules (front and back sides). For best protection against physical damage, the Contractor shall consider modules that are rated for "Very Severe Hail" as per ANSI 4473. Table 1 below provides specific data on front and back load ratings.

Specification_Description: This section covers any module or racking feature that can be added to increase the durability of modules under high wind loading.
Specification_Template_Language: The Contractor will consult with module and racking manufacturers to discuss product options that can be selected to increase module strength and prevent module cell cracking.

Specification_Description: This section describes the requirements for racking/mounting systems in regards to severe weather, codes, and best practices.
Specification_Template_Language:
Specify PV panels and rail/rack systems that have UL 1703 and UL 2703 listing (as applicable) and an ICC AC 428 evaluation report.

In regions that experience high wind environments greater than 70 MPH, a third rail system shall be installed (Figure 1).

Racking rails shall be mounted portrait (perpendicular to the long side of module), with spacing as prescribed by the module manufacturer (Figure 1).

The Contractor shall not utilize simple friction clamps, as seen in Figure 2, as this may lead to "domino effect" loss of an entire row of modules.

The Contractor, when possible, shall:

  • Utilize through bolts on the modules at the end of the rows.
  • Utilize bolts paired with a nut and/or washer to enable fastener system to meet DIN 25201 locking standards.
  • Ensure that the racking manufacturer or project engineer specifies a torque rating on the fasteners.
  • Utilize friction module clamps of the "U" and "H" shape, as seen in Figure 3 below. The intent is to prevent total loss of all modules in a row due to domino effects.
  • Utilize friction module clamps at least 3" in length.

Specification_Description: This section describes the importance of working with module and racking manufacturers for the best outcome.
Specification_Template_Language: The Contractor shall consult with module and rack manufacturers to select the module clamps, clamp locations, and quantity of clamps to achieve the greatest durability under wind, hail, and snow loading.

Specification_Description: This section describes the types of structural clamping systems that Contractors cannot use.
Specification_Template_Language: Under no circumstances shall clamping systems be used to hold underlying structural frame members together (Figures 1 and 2).

Specification_Title: Use of Self-Tapping Sheet Metal Screws
Specification_Description: This section describes the requirement that the Contractor must not use self-tapping sheet metal screws for any reason, unless approved by the agency.
Specification_Template_Language: Under no circumstances shall self-tapping sheet metal screws of any grade be used to hold PV system structural elements together or to mount conduit, electrical enclosures, metering, or weather station components.

Specification_Title: Use of Self-Tapping Sheet Metal Screws (Advanced)
Specification_Description: This section describes the requirement that the Contractor must not use self-tapping sheet metal screws for any reason, unless approved by the agency.
Specification_Template_Language: Under no circumstances shall self-tapping sheet metal screws of any grade be used to hold PV system structural elements together or to mount conduit, electrical enclosures, metering, or weather station components. Further, these screws shall not be used for field-assembled fencing, lighting, security camera systems, or communications equipment. Any proposed use of self-tapping screws must be pre-approved by the agency Contracting Officer or Contracting Officer's Technical Representative (COTR) having authority. Any such screws approved for use must be SAE 316-grade stainless suitable for marine applications.

Specification_Description: This section describes the requirement that the Contractor not use fasteners not rated for wind-induced vibration and thermal cycling loosening.
Specification_Template_Language: Under no circumstances shall split washers, nylocks, and or serrated flange nuts be used to provide fastener locking capability.¬† Only fasteners that meet DIN-25101 ratings for locking shall be used.

Specification_Title: Special Note on the Use of Chemical Locking Compounds
Specification_Description: This section describes the limits of using chemical locking compounds on threaded fasteners.
Specification_Template_Language: Chemical locking compounds can be used effectively to lock fasteners, but shall be avoided when possible due to lack of field adjustability and ability to audit. These compounds have unknown durability when exposed to UV, humidity, and heat.
Specification_Background: Chemical locking compounds can be used effectively to lock fasteners; however, Contractors should be aware of three significant limitations to these products. Thread locking compounds prevents re-tightening should a bolted joint lose its pre-load on fastener. Additionally, chemical compounds prevent torque audits. It is unclear how durable locking compounds will be when exposed to heat, moisture, sunlight, and corrosive dust and marine air.

Specification_Description: This section describes the processes the Contractor must adhere to in regards to torqueing all fasteners to the recommended manufacturer specifications.
Specification_Template_Language:
Each subassembly shall be torqued to manufacturer's specification using torque wrenches or drivers designed to provide calibrated and metered forces and be rated by ISO 6780-2. For field-assembled components of disparate manufacturers or from custom fabrications, a structural engineer shall specify torque ratings and field assembly procedures to be included in submittals and construction drawings. These torque ratings and procedures shall be included in operations and maintenance manuals for later use.

For fasteners holding friction or clamping forces, Section 3.3 of ICC AC 428, 2012 shall apply.

The Contractor shall utilize an established torque auditing procedure.

Specification_Description: This section describes the processes the Contractor must adhere to in regards to torqueing all fasteners to the recommended manufacturer specifications.
Specification_Template_Language:
Each subassembly shall be torqued to manufacturer's specification using torque wrenches or drivers designed to provide calibrated and metered forces and be rated by ISO 6780-2. For field-assembled components of disparate manufacturers or from custom fabrications, a structural engineer shall specify torque ratings and field assembly procedures to be included in submittals and construction drawings. These torque ratings and procedures shall be included in operations and maintenance manuals for later use.

For fasteners holding friction or clamping forces, Section 3.3 of ICC AC 428, 2012 shall apply.

At a minimum, field assembly and audit procedures shall include the following:

  • Threaded fasteners shall be pre- or field-treated with anti-spalling compounds.
  • The fastener must be torqued to the rating to achieve full loading, and it shall be assumed that this pre-loading will relax as Washer Electrical Equipment Bonds (WEEBS) and metal surfaces mold and mate into each other.
  • Allow metal surfaces of bolted joints to mate after the initial torque rating is achieved. Each fastener is to be torqued to rating a second time.
  • The Contractor must mark each fastener torqued with a metal marker to indicate complete installation of the fastener. Figure 1 shows the marked nut, indicating that torquing has been performed.
  • As part of the commission process, an independent agent shall audit a randomly selected group of fasteners for proper torque. The commissioning agency shall use the "First-Movement" technique to confirm that proper torque has been achieved.
  • Auditing of bolted joints shall at a minimum use the "First Movement Method" of auditing and confirming torque ratings.
  • Mark fastener and material as shown in Figure 2.
  • Set the torquing tool to the specified setting.
  • Turn the fastener in the direction to tighten it (often clockwise) and note if the fastener turns substantially until reaching the specified torque rating. This will be indicated when the mark on the nut no longer aligns with that on the surface of the clamped material. Figure 2 shows the marked bolt and clamped part. If misalignment of the mark on the fastener and clamped part is minor, then this shall be considered within the limits of the specification. However, if it is as shown in Figure 3, the mark on the fastener and the clamped part is greatly misaligned, and this is out of spec. A fastener that moves more than 3 degrees during the torque audit shall be classified as out of spec.
  • If the audit reveals fasteners out of specification with the torque ratings:
    • Audit additional fasteners to gain a better sense of what percentage of fasteners are out of specification.
    • If the quantity (%) of fasteners is out of torque specification by more than 1-3 percent, all fasteners will need to be re-torqued.
    • Re-audit the fasteners to confirm torque ratings have been achieved.

Specification_Description: This section describes requirements for soft joint bolting of tubular materials in the structure of the PV system.
Specification_Template_Language:
In instances where tubular materials are bolted together forming "soft joints" (Figures 1 and 2), the following bolting requirements apply:

  • The project engineer shall specify torque ratings to achieve proper pre-loading on a bolt that provides needed clamping forces without collapsing the joint.
  • Use of a locking fastener that can compensate for joint relaxation due to loss of a bolt pre-load (Figure 3) shall be used. Use of spring/cupped washers to be specified.
  • The product or project engineer shall be used to maintain bolt pre-load with soft joints.

Specification_Description: This section describes the requirements for PV system components to be corrosion resistant.
Specification_Template_Language: All PV hardware and rack components shall be of corrosion-resistant material, such as stainless steel SAE grade 316. Aluminum and hot-dipped galvanized steel may be used for non-marine environments under ASTM A123 specifications. Fasteners shall be compliant with ASTM F2329.

Specification_Description: This section describes requirements for PV system grounding components.
Specification_Template_Language: Components in the array grounding system shall consist only of copper, brass, and stainless steel componentry.

Specification_Description: This section describes requirements for PV system grounding components.
Specification_Template_Language: Components in the array grounding system shall consist only of copper, brass, and stainless steel componentry. Under no circumstances shall grounding lugs be mounted using standard carbon steel fasteners. Grounding lug set screws must be of the same metal as the lug or stainless steel to prevent galvanic corrosion.

Specification_Description: This section describes best practices for wire management of the PV array(s).
Specification_Template_Language:
Under no circumstances shall plastic (non-metallic) cable-ties be used to secure and organize array wiring exterior to electrical enclosures. Exterior, long-life plastic ties shall not be used. Use of purpose-built hangers or stainless steel ties or other stainless or galvanized hardware shall be used in wire management.

Wire shall not lie exposed directly on the roof surface or ground. Long horizontal conduit runs shall have expansion unions every 30' in order to reduce wire abrasion caused by fixed couplings.

Array wiring shall not be routed in a way that results in direct sun exposure.

Specification_Description: This section describes best practices for wire management of the PV array(s).
Specification_Template_Language:
Under no circumstances shall plastic (non-metallic) cable-ties be used to secure and organize array wiring exterior to electrical enclosures. Exterior, long-life plastic ties shall not be used. Stainless steel ties or other stainless or galvanized hardware shall be used in wire management. Ties shall be UL-listed and have a minimum breaking strength of 40 lbs.

No mast heads entering the top or side of electrical enclosures shall be used to route string wiring into cabinets. String electrical conductors are to be routed through the bottom of the electrical enclosures to prevent wind-driven water infiltration.

Wire cannot lie exposed directly on the roof surface or ground. Long horizontal conduit runs shall have expansion unions every 30' in order to reduce wire abrasion caused by fixed couplings. Couplings and expansion unions must use anti-abrasion bushings. All power wiring shall be attached to the system components by the use of strain reliefs or cable clamps, unless enclosed in conduit.

Specification_Description: This section provides guidance on preventing water intrusion in conduit.
Specification_Template_Language:
Conduit routing and fittings must be selected to prevent water intrusion into all electrical equipment. Conduit must connect through the bottom of enclosures and provide fittings to allow water to drain prior to entering the electrical enclosure.

Any exterior PVC conduit must be Schedule 80. All exterior wiring downstream of combiner boxes or string inverters must be in conduit.

Specification_Description: This section provides guidance on preventing water from entering electrical enclosures and identifies the minimum NEMA rating that must be used for all enclosures.
Specification_Template_Language: All exterior housings must be continuously welded, NEMA 4 (or better), fully gasketed, continuously hinged (piano hinge) with three-point door closure clamps, and designed to prevent water intrusion from hose down, splashing water, and wind-driven rain. Gaskets must be molded and of one continuous shape, with no seams.

Specification_Description: This section provides guidance on preventing water from entering electrical enclosures and identifies the minimum NEMA rating that must be used for all enclosures.
Specification_Template_Language: All exterior housings must be continuously welded, NEMA 4 (or better), fully gasketed, continuously hinged (piano hinge) with three-point door closure clamps, and designed to prevent water intrusion from hose down, splashing water, and wind-driven rain. Gaskets must be molded and of one continuous shape, with no seams. All equipment mounted to the interior of the enclosure shall use back plates to minimize exterior cabinet penetrations. Minimum mounting height of enclosures shall be based on the 100-year flood plain and surge levels.

Specification_Description: This section describes the disconnect configuration required for transformers.
Specification_Template_Language: Each transformer must have external and lockable disconnects, one on the primary side and a separate one on the secondary side.

Specification_Description: This section provides guidance on the best locations to install electrical equipment.
Specification_Template_Language:
Major electrical components, including the inverter, isolation transformer, and metering shall be installed in code-compliant enclosures. Components shall be located indoors whenever feasible, in ventilated (or air conditioned) utility rooms and where space and codes allow. In climates and locations with high heat and/or humidity, Contractor shall install air conditioning in room housing major electrical components.

When inverters and major electrical components are located outdoors they shall be protected from direct exposure to weather (sun, rain, snow, and sleet). A simple open-sided shed roof structure is sufficient, as is a location under shaded carport arrays. Under no circumstances shall inverters be located on roofs in direct sun. In areas affected by severe weather events (hurricanes, flooding, monsoons, etc.), special consideration must be given when identifying locations for major electrical equipment.

The Contractor shall coordinate with the Contracting Officer's Technical Representative (COTR) and Electrical Engineer (EE) regarding locations and appearance of all equipment, including PV modules, conduit, inverters, disconnect switches, wire ways, and control and monitoring equipment. The COTR and EE must approve all locations prior to installation.

Specification_Description: This section describes the expectations that the materials used in the project shall last the expected service life of 30 years.
Specification_Template_Language: Unless noted otherwise, all materials furnished for the project shall have an expected service life of thirty (30) years or more, given the unique service conditions of each PV system site. Equipment warranties (modules, inverters, etc.) are shorter than the expected service life. With a 30-year system life, it is common and well understood by industry that inverters and a small percentage of failed modules would need to be replaced, though the system as a whole would provide at least 30 years of service. Agencies shall seek the type of equipment and workmanship that can result in a 30-year system.

Specification_Description: This section describes the requirements that any new transformers installed as part of the project be high-efficiency.
Specification_Template_Language: Any new transformers installed as part of the project shall be high-efficiency transformers. All such transformers shall comply with "NEMA Premium Efficiency" and be of amorphous steel core with bio-based oil.

Specification_Description: This section describes the site-specific conditions that the equipment must withstand.
Specification_Template_Language: Materials shall be designed to withstand the year-round temperatures and conditions to which they are exposed (sunlight, heat, rain, cold, wind, seismic activity, salt air, fog, marine corrosiveness, etc.)

Specification_Description: This section requires that the Contractor use the same manufacturer and product line for all components of the PV system.
Specification_Template_Language: All modules, inverters, and electrical switchgear are to be of the same manufacturer and product line for each PV system.

Specification_Description: This section requires that all equipment used for the project be "out-of-the-box" new.
Specification_Template_Language: The Government shall not accept used, reconditioned, after-market, or grey-market products or equipment. The Contractor may be held responsible for damages to the Government if the Contractor supplies used, reconditioned, after-market, or grey-market products

Specification_Description: This section requires the PV system meet all marking requirements from local, state, and federal codes to ensure safety of all personnel.
Specification_Template_Language:
Strict conformance to system marking requirements of PV systems and their components is crucial for the safety of operators, service personnel, emergency responders, and others. General PV system labeling requirements, as per NEC 690 Ch. VI and specific requirements from Articles 690 and 705. Include all required and desired labeling language in the design drawings for agency review.

Electrical equipment and components used in PV systems shall have markings that identify the manufacturer, size, type, ratings, hazard warnings, and other specifications. Equipment markings shall never be removed and shall be able to withstand the environmental conditions in which the equipment is installed (e.g., "UV rated" for outdoor labels). Markings must be visible or easily accessible during and after installation. The Contractor shall be responsible for all field-applied markings as required by local, state, and federal codes.

Specification_Title: Array Glare and Glint Prevention Analysis - Impacts to Aviation
Specification_Description: This section describes the analysis the Contractor must conduct to meet Federal Aviation Administration requirements in regards to glare and glint.
Specification_Template_Language:
The Contractor shall conduct a glare analysis to determine the glare impact on any local neighborhoods and/or nearby airports (within 10 miles). The glare analysis should use a tool approved by the agency CO. The glare analysis shall be conducted after the conceptual design is approved by the Government. The glare analysis may need to be repeated if changes are made to the size, shape, or orientation of the PV project, as these changes could have an effect on glare. At a minimum, the information required for the analysis shall include:

  • Location (depicted on the map; including address or latitude/longitude)
  • Array orientation and panel tilt
  • Module surface material and whether anti-reflective coatings will be used on the PV modules
  • PV module layout and size of the array
  • Tracking or fixed configuration, height of the modules above the ground (highest point)

If the glare analysis shows that the glare for a particular PV array does not meet acceptable levels, the design shall be modified as much as practicable to minimize glare. If it is not possible to modify the PV array design to reduce glare to an acceptable level, the specific PV array should not be included and an alternative location proposed.

Specification_Description: This section describes requirements for protection from lightning.
Specification_Template_Language: For areas that experience frequent storms containing lightning events, a dedicated or separate grounding electrode shall be added for the lightning suppression, as described in NEC 2017 Section 690.47(B). The "Auxiliary Grounding Electrodes" must be bonded to the premises' grounding-electrode system.

Specification_Description: This section provides guidance on how agencies can procure high-quality and durable PV modules that are designed and manufactured to last the full contract period.
Specification_Template_Language:
There are three common ways to screen modules for quality:

Method 1: Minimum accelerated test standards:

Request that Contractors provide during the submittal phase the results of the following minimum accelerated tests:

  • Thermal Cycling (as per IEC 61215:2016) x 600 cycles
  • Damp Heat (as per IEC 61215:2016) x 2,000 hours
  • Dynamic Mechanical Load (as per IEC TS 62782:2016) x 1,000 cycles + Thermal Cycling (as per IEC 61215:2016) x 50 cycles + Humidity Freeze (as per IEC 61215:2016) x 10 cycles
  • Potential Induced Degradation (as per IEC 63204) x 192 hours
  • Third-party PAN file measurements (as per IEC 61853-1)
  • Incident Angle Modifier (IAM) coefficients (as per IEC 61853-2)
  • Light Induced Degradation (as per IEC 61215:2016) and Light and Elevated Temperature Induced Degradation testing (as per draft IEC 61215)

The modules delivered to the project site must have the same bill of materials (BOM) as tested.

Method 2: Existing test lab results made public:

Some certified test labs share results publicly under pre-negotiated agreements with module manufacturers. These public lists of tested modules are not comprehensive but do provide a very convenient source of information on brands that have been tests.

One public source is the annual test results published by PV Evolution Labs (PVEL): https://www.pvel.com/pv-scorecard/

Method 3: For large multi-megawatt projects:

For very large utility scale projects (several megawatts in size), customers can request testing of a statistically meaningful group of modules from the same batch slated to be shipped to the project site. Specialized third-party consulting firms perform this service for industry stakeholders and do on-the-spot inspections of manufacturing facilities to verify quality programs.
Specification_Background:
Failures with most solar PV system components are easily addressed and represent only short-term loss of power output and inconvenience. However, if modules fail in large numbers, this is a serious economic and life safety issue for both the Contractor and the host agency. Large numbers of module failures represent potential total loss of savings, life-safety hazards, property damage, and time-consuming and embarrassing circumstances. If the agency site is located in a high fire-prone area, then module quality should be an imperative.

Since safety, long-term quality, and performance are intrinsically linked, only modules passing independent test lab accelerated testing may be used. The National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) Qualification Plus (https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy14osti/60950.pdf) testing guidelines provide details on the minimum testing conditions.

Alternatively, some certified test labs have expanded/extended test standards based on the Qualification Plus (QP) testing regime and provide important testing services to module manufacturers and system owners. The QP program represents what should be included in a minimum testing regime by any certified lab. One test lab, PVEL, has made its test results available in an annual report called the PVEL-2019 PV Module Reliability Scorecard report. This report provides an easy way to find tested and scored modules, however, it is only updated annually and does not cover many manufacturers and model numbers on the market.

The primary existing design qualification standards International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) 61215 (crystalline cells) and IEC 61646 (thin film) have been successful in preventing initial early life module failures but are insufficient in predicting failure modes seen in the field over time. A set of accelerated tests have been developed and refined that are adequate for predicting module longevity.

http://www.solarabcs.org/about/publications/reports/accelerated testing/pdfs/SolarABCs-33- 2013.pdf

Upcoming standards can be monitored at the International PV Quality Assurance Task Force (PAT) website: https://www.pvqat.org/index.html

Specification_Description: This section provides guidance on how agencies can procure high-quality and durable inverters that are designed and manufactured to last the expected lifespan.
Specification_Template_Language: Only inverters passing independent test lab accelerated testing may be used.
Specification_Background: Unlike modules, there are few good resources for buyers and owners in selecting inverters that can provide predictable service life. In 2019 PVEL developed a first-of-a-kind scorecard based on a regime of accelerated tests.

Specification_Description: This section provides guidance on how agencies can procure high-quality and durable inverters that are designed and manufactured to last the expected lifespan.
Specification_Template_Language:
Method 1: Minimum accelerated test standards:

Request that Contractors provide during the submittal phase the results of the following minimum accelerated tests:

  • High Temperature Operating Environment: 65°C full power operation for 1,000 hours of sustained operation. The inverter is provided with 1.05 or greater than full power and at a DC voltage that provides the most stress on the inverter-switching architecture for the duration of the testing.
  • Powered Thermal Cycling Exposure: Powered thermal cycling between -30°C and 65°C with an inverter provided with full-rated power during ramp from cold temperature through to high temperature dwell. Following the high temperature dwell, the inverter is removed from power to aid in cooling to minimum cyclic temperature.
  • High temperature and humidity exposure: 65°C, 85% relative humidity for 1,000 hours of high-voltage low-power exposure. The inverter is maintained at maximum operational system voltage and ~10% output power for the duration of the exposure conditions.
  • Damp Heat (passive testing to IEC 61215 1,000 hours)
  • Humidity Freeze (passive testing to IEC 61215 10 cycles)

    Method 2: Use publicly available certified inverter lab test results:

    One public source is the annual test results published by PV Evolution Labs (PVEL): https://www.pvel.com/inverter-scorecard.
Specification_Background: Unlike modules, there are few good resources for buyers and owners in selecting inverters that can provide predictable service life. In 2019 PVEL developed a first-of-a-kind scorecard based on a regime of accelerated tests.

Specification_Description: This section describes cybersecurity requirements that must be met at Government facilities for PV system monitoring to be installed.
Specification_Template_Language:
All PV system monitoring and control equipment installed at Government sites must be granted Authorization To Operate (ATO) through agency cybersecurity officials. There are three aspects of cybersecurity agency requirements that Contractors shall anticipate:

  • Secure network connections between the site hardware (data acquisition equipment, meters, sensors, instruments) and third-party data collection servers.
  • A secured website that hosts the agency's data dashboard.
  • A secure data storage and retrieval means.

    • The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Act of 2018 mandated the development of a subagency under the Department of Homeland Security called the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA). The CISA website is a useful source of guidance for Contractors and agencies.

Specification_Template_Language: All data collected into a clouded server and stored is the exclusive property of the Government. The Contractor must seek the Government's written permission if data are to be disseminated to any entity not party to this contract.

Specification_Description: This section describes the requirements the Contractor must adhere to when operating and maintaining the PV equipment.
Specification_Template_Language: During the Term, the Contractor shall maintain the system monitoring equipment set forth in this section below at the site, or such other monitoring equipment as is otherwise provided by the Government periodically ("System Monitoring Equipment"). The Contractor shall use commercially reasonable efforts to ensure and monitor the internet connectivity of the System Monitoring Equipment such that data regarding the performance of and output from the system shall be communicated electronically to the Contractor on a continuous basis.

Specification_Description: This section describes the performance requirements the PV system must meet during the contract period.
Specification_Template_Language:
The Contractor shall maintain the system to achieve a Weather Corrected Performance Ratio of at least 0.9 over any monitoring period. Calculation of the performance ratio shall take into account expected degradation due to age, snow cover, severe wind events, and or other conditions deemed beyond the Contractor's control by the Contracting Officer.

Determinations of system performance during the life of the contract shall use the "NREL Performance Ratio" methodology as detailed in Attachment A of NREL's "PV Operations and Maintenance (PV O&M) Best Practices Guide" (https://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy19osti/73822.pdf).

This performance warranty shall apply for the 20-year performance period but excludes the construction and startup period.

For third-party owned systems: If a Fair Market Value (FMV) purchase is contemplated between Government and Contractor, the Weather Corrected Performance Ratio shall establish the baseline to be used in any price negotiations if professional appraiser retained requests system performance data.

If the performance falls below the minimum required by the contract, the Contractor or Subcontractor, at the Contractor or Subcontractor's expense, shall replace or repair the defective equipment and or adverse condition.
